hints.content:
Differentiating both sides of the equation $F(x)=\dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\,$ gives


$\qquad F\,^\prime(x)=\dfrac{d}{dx}\Bigg (\dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\Bigg )\,$.

Thus

$\qquad F\,^\prime(x)=\dfrac{g(x)\,f\,^\prime(x)-f(x)\,g\,^\prime(x)}{(g(x))^2}$
On the graph, we locate the points $\big(4,f(4)\big)$ and $\big(4,g(4)\big)\,$, to discover that $f(4)=0$  and  $g(4)=-1\,$.

Similarly, we need to look at the graph to find derivative values $f\,^\prime(4)$ and $g\,\,^\prime(4)\,$.

Since both $f$ and $g$ are composed of line segments, the derivative values are equal to the slopes of the line segments in the neighborhood of $x=4\,$.


From the graph, we see that the slope of the graph of $f$ at $x=4$ is $\,\dfrac{1}{2}\,$, so $f\,^\prime(4)=\dfrac{1}{2}\,$.
Similarly, the slope of the graph of $g$ at $x=4$ is  $\,\dfrac{-3}{2}\,$, so $g^\prime(4)=\dfrac{-3}{2}\,$.

Finally we substitute these values into the quotient rule giving

$\qquad\displaystyle F\,^\prime(4)=\dfrac{g(4)\,f\,^\prime(4)-f(4)\,g\,^\prime(4)}{\big(g(4)\big)^2}\,$. 

This gives $\qquad\displaystyle F\,^\prime(4)=\dfrac{-1\cdot\,\frac{1}{2}-0\cdot\frac{-3}{2}}{(-1)^2} =\dfrac{-1}{2}\,$.

question.content:
If $F(x)=\dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}$, where $f$ and $g$ have the graphs shown below, what is the value of $F\,^\prime(4)$?

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/96589f0523b9d4579df7c41c5dd7dee719297f91.png)

[[☃ radio 1]]
